abstract:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management (DFRM) gathers data from various Nez Perce hatcheries through a specific method. This approach involves collecting information on fish at 18 different facilities. These facilities include adult traps, weirs, holding ponds, spawning sites, juvenile rearing areas, and release sites.

The necessity of this method lies in the need for comprehensive data on Nez Perce hatchery operations. By collecting information from each unique site, species, and run-timing, DFRM ensures that accurate and up-to-date records are maintained. This data is crucial for effective fish population management and conservation efforts.

Collaborative or shared management of sites is common, with the Nez Perce Tribe leading, contributing, or assisting in these partnerships. The method's specificity to each hatchery allows for tailored strategies based on individual site conditions and species requirements.

This approach solves several issues, such as ensuring that accurate data is collected and recorded, enabling informed decision-making regarding hatchery operations, and promoting effective collaboration with co-managers or assistance from other organizations when needed.

description:
The Nez Perce Tribe (NPT) Department of Fisheries Resources Management (DFRM) gathers hatchery evaluation data from fish sourced at 18 distinct facilities. The hatchery types where this data is obtained encompass adult traps, picket weirs, adult holding ponds, spawning facilities, primary and secondary juvenile rearing locations, and acclimation release sites.

At adult traps, fish are captured for evaluation before being released back into the wild. Picket weirs, another hatchery type, serve as a means of collecting mature fish through a series of weirs or fences, which are typically constructed with wooden posts and wire mesh.

Spawning facilities are essential for the reproduction of fish species in controlled environments. These structures enable DFRM to collect data on spawning fish populations and monitor their reproductive success.

Primary juvenile rearing locations refer to hatcheries where young fish (fry) are initially raised under controlled conditions, receiving nutrition and protection from predators. Secondary juvenile rearing sites serve as the next phase of development for fish, focusing on growing them closer to their target size before release into natural habitats.

Acclimation release sites provide a gradual transition for juvenile fish from hatchery conditions to the wild. In these areas, fish are acclimated to the environmental conditions and learn vital survival skills before being released.

The management of each site is executed exclusively by the Nez Perce Tribe, collaboratively with co-managers, or in an assisting role. This methodology is unique to individual hatcheries, species, and run-timing (seasonal patterns). The effectiveness of hatchery operations is closely monitored, ensuring that the data collected remains relevant and contributes to sustainable fishery populations.
